update.description:
This PR sets the file structure for logging code. It is meant to be compatible with the soon-to-be components feature of ignition-cmake. Nothing interesting happens in the files added; they're present to allow committing the folder structure.

Once this PR is merged I'll change the location of the schema file in pull request #244 to be somewhere in this new folder.
update.title: Code layout for record/playback

content.raw:
When I was implementing the `Components` branch of `ign-cmake`, that's how I originally structured the directories for `ign-common`. It can work, but I ran into some rather irritating hurdles: You end up needing to deal with the logic of whether or not to build/install the component library in multiple places.

In other words, somewhere in `ign-transport/src/` or `ign-transport/src/log/` you need to decide whether or not to build the component library. Then in `ign-transport/include/ignition/transport/` you need to decide whether or not to include the headers. Then in `tests/` you need to decide whether to build tests that require the specific component. This means that you need to make sure the decision to build or install gets propagated along multiple paths in the build system, and that it's used consistently in all of those places.

By contrast, if you create a top-level subdirectory for the component, you can isolate all this logic into a single place and choose to skip over the entire subdirectory if you don't want to build the component.

A working example of this can be found in [the Components branch of `ign-common`](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/f62beda459395d9b96efface80a6f5060da74086/?at=Components). In that directory structure, we have the top-level subdirectories `av`, `events`, and `graphics`, each referring to a different component with a different set of dependencies.

In the top-level [CMakeLists.txt](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/src/f62beda459395d9b96efface80a6f5060da74086/CMakeLists.txt?at=Components&fileviewer=file-view-default) the macro `ign_configure_build(QUIT_IF_BUILD_ERRORS COMPONENTS av graphics events)` will skip over any component subdirectories whose dependencies were not satisfied (or if a user has specified `SKIP_<component>`). Inside each of the component subdirectories, the build scripts can safely assume that everything inside of it is meant to be built and installed. This lets us write scripts for components that are almost identical to the scripts we write for the main libraries (with a few exceptions, like using `ign_add_component(~)` instead of `ign_create_main_library(~)`).

We're not planning on using the `Components` branch of `ign-cmake` for this project (yet), but I think we'd benefit from this directory structure if we decide to have logging as a separate library. If logging isn't a separate library, then the source files should just go in `ign-transport/src`.
content.html:
When I was implementing the Components branch of ign-cmake, that's how I originally structured the directories for ign-common. It can work, but I ran into some rather irritating hurdles: You end up needing to deal with the logic of whether or not to build/install the component library in multiple places.

In other words, somewhere in ign-transport/src/ or ign-transport/src/log/ you need to decide whether or not to build the component library. Then in ign-transport/include/ignition/transport/ you need to decide whether or not to include the headers. Then in tests/ you need to decide whether to build tests that require the specific component. This means that you need to make sure the decision to build or install gets propagated along multiple paths in the build system, and that it's used consistently in all of those places.

By contrast, if you create a top-level subdirectory for the component, you can isolate all this logic into a single place and choose to skip over the entire subdirectory if you don't want to build the component.

A working example of this can be found in the Components branch of ign-common. In that directory structure, we have the top-level subdirectories av, events, and graphics, each referring to a different component with a different set of dependencies.

In the top-level CMakeLists.txt the macro ign_configure_build(QUIT_IF_BUILD_ERRORS COMPONENTS av graphics events) will skip over any component subdirectories whose dependencies were not satisfied (or if a user has specified SKIP_<component>). Inside each of the component subdirectories, the build scripts can safely assume that everything inside of it is meant to be built and installed. This lets us write scripts for components that are almost identical to the scripts we write for the main libraries (with a few exceptions, like using ign_add_component(~) instead of ign_create_main_library(~)).

We're not planning on using the Components branch of ign-cmake for this project (yet), but I think we'd benefit from this directory structure if we decide to have logging as a separate library. If logging isn't a separate library, then the source files should just go in ign-transport/src.

update.title: Code layout for record/playback

content.raw: What if we create the `log` directory inside `src` and inside `include/ignition/transport`?
content.html: What if we create the log directory inside src and inside include/ignition/transport?

content.raw:
In my experience, the most idiomatic use of namespaces is to organize classes into the libraries that they belong to (with a few special cases, like the `internal` or `detail` namespaces for hiding implementation details). Ideally, a directory structure should have some kind of 1:1 correspondence with the name of the library whose source files it contains. As a result, namespaces should end up naturally matching the directory structure of the source code.

If we want the logger API to be a part of `ignition-transport`, then it should use the `ignition::transport` namespace and live in the `ign-transport/src` directory (with its headers in `ign-transport/include/ignition/transport`).

I see two disadvantages to this:

1. `SQLite3` becomes a required dependency of `ignition-transport`. This probably isn't a major disadvantage given how ubiquitous `SQLite3` is. It's probably Windows users who will hurt the most from it, because they'll have to make sure that `SQLite3` can be found by `ignition-transport` at build time and at run time, even if they don't want to use the logging features.

2. The source code and API of logging gets sort of blended into the rest of the source code for `ignition-transport`, even though it has its own dependency and is serving a different role than the overall `ign-transport` library. If a refactoring is desired in the future, it'll be harder when logging is blended into everything else.

If we don't care about those disadvantages, then we can just put the logging API into the rest of the source code tree, give it the namespace `ignition::transport`, and make `SQLite3` a required dependency.

Edit: Also, tying back to your comment about "multiple files with a common purpose", I think that's often a good rule of thumb for where to draw the line between separate libraries (especially if you account for dependencies as well).
content.html:
In my experience, the most idiomatic use of namespaces is to organize classes into the libraries that they belong to (with a few special cases, like the internal or detail namespaces for hiding implementation details). Ideally, a directory structure should have some kind of 1:1 correspondence with the name of the library whose source files it contains. As a result, namespaces should end up naturally matching the directory structure of the source code.

If we want the logger API to be a part of ignition-transport, then it should use the ignition::transport namespace and live in the ign-transport/src directory (with its headers in ign-transport/include/ignition/transport).

I see two disadvantages to this:

  1. SQLite3 becomes a required dependency of ignition-transport. This probably isn't a major disadvantage given how ubiquitous SQLite3 is. It's probably Windows users who will hurt the most from it, because they'll have to make sure that SQLite3 can be found by ignition-transport at build time and at run time, even if they don't want to use the logging features.

  2. The source code and API of logging gets sort of blended into the rest of the source code for ignition-transport, even though it has its own dependency and is serving a different role than the overall ign-transport library. If a refactoring is desired in the future, it'll be harder when logging is blended into everything else.

If we don't care about those disadvantages, then we can just put the logging API into the rest of the source code tree, give it the namespace ignition::transport, and make SQLite3 a required dependency.

Edit: Also, tying back to your comment about "multiple files with a common purpose", I think that's often a good rule of thumb for where to draw the line between separate libraries (especially if you account for dependencies as well).

content.raw: I'd vote for a separate namespace in that case.
content.html: I'd vote for a separate namespace in that case.

content.raw: But we can start with an executable, no need to do everything at the same time.
content.html: But we can start with an executable, no need to do everything at the same time.

content.raw: Based on the API in the confluence page there will be 7ish header/source files.
content.html: Based on the API in the confluence page there will be 7ish header/source files.

content.raw: I think integration with ignition-tools would be great.
content.html: I think integration with ignition-tools would be great.

content.raw: It is since no install rule was added. I can add one. What are the expectations on the shipped product? Is an executable good enough, or is there a hard requirement to do the extra work to integrate with `ignition-tools`?
content.html: It is since no install rule was added. I can add one. What are the expectations on the shipped product? Is an executable good enough, or is there a hard requirement to do the extra work to integrate with ignition-tools?

content.raw: I don't see the new `.so` installed after running `make install`. Is it expected?
content.html: I don't see the new .so installed after running make install. Is it expected?

content.raw: To me, a namespace groups multiple files with a common purpose. If you're planning to create multiple files for logging, I'd create the namespace. If there are only a few files for now, we can live with them in the current flat structure.
content.html: To me, a namespace groups multiple files with a common purpose. If you're planning to create multiple files for logging, I'd create the namespace. If there are only a few files for now, we can live with them in the current flat structure.

content.raw:
I think I misunderstood the email thread; I had the impression the path forward agreed upon was to put logging in a separate folder.

@caguero What are your thoughts?
content.html:
I think I misunderstood the email thread; I had the impression the path forward agreed upon was to put logging in a separate folder.

@caguero What are your thoughts?

content.raw:
Yes, add sqlite3 as a dependency. This PR can become the Log class and a dependency on sqlite3. I'm ignoring sunk cost.

It's not guaranteed that we want logging to be a separate library. Adding a new library and namespace is based on speculation, not on a requirement.
content.html:
Yes, add sqlite3 as a dependency. This PR can become the Log class and a dependency on sqlite3. I'm ignoring sunk cost.

It's not guaranteed that we want logging to be a separate library. Adding a new library and namespace is based on speculation, not on a requirement.

content.raw:
Do we want to add `SQLite3` as a required dependency to `ign-transport`?

I'm honestly not clear on what we accomplish by baking it all into one library, especially since this PR already takes care of all the legwork for having it as its own library. It seems like doing that would add work now (undoing this PR and moving the code into `ign-transport`) and then add more work in the future if we want to make SQLite3+logging optional.
content.html:
Do we want to add SQLite3 as a required dependency to ign-transport?

I'm honestly not clear on what we accomplish by baking it all into one library, especially since this PR already takes care of all the legwork for having it as its own library. It seems like doing that would add work now (undoing this PR and moving the code into ign-transport) and then add more work in the future if we want to make SQLite3+logging optional.

content.raw: For this stage, logging also shouldn't be part of a different library. Bake it all into the main ign-transport library.
content.html: For this stage, logging also shouldn't be part of a different library. Bake it all into the main ign-transport library.

content.raw:
I would contend that namespaces reduce complexity by organizing code into clear conceptual units, and that leaving out the namespace will add complexity by forcing us to remember that the `ignition::transport::Log` class is secretly part of a different library than `ignition-transport`.

On the other hand, if the class is named `igition::transport::logging::Log`, then it's easy to recognize that it belongs to the `ignition-transport-logging` library.
content.html:
I would contend that namespaces reduce complexity by organizing code into clear conceptual units, and that leaving out the namespace will add complexity by forcing us to remember that the ignition::transport::Log class is secretly part of a different library than ignition-transport.

On the other hand, if the class is named igition::transport::logging::Log, then it's easy to recognize that it belongs to the ignition-transport-logging library.

content.raw: Understood, but I'd still like to start as simple as possible. There is one class, and no components. During the prototype stage it'd be easier to keep things as simple as possible. Once we have a more concrete example, then we can add complexity with a clear understanding of why the complexity is needed.
content.html: Understood, but I'd still like to start as simple as possible. There is one class, and no components. During the prototype stage it'd be easier to keep things as simple as possible. Once we have a more concrete example, then we can add complexity with a clear understanding of why the complexity is needed.

content.raw: While there isn't a technical need for the namespace, I think the subdirectory is needed for ignition-cmake components.
content.html: While there isn't a technical need for the namespace, I think the subdirectory is needed for ignition-cmake components.

content.raw:
The need (at least in my view) is that the logging framework will depend on SQLite3. Rather than making SQLite3 a required dependency of `ign-transport`, we can create a `log` (or `logging`) component library, and thereby isolate the dependency to the optional component.

Adding a namespace provides both developers and users with a clear delineation between the main library and the component library.
content.html:
The need (at least in my view) is that the logging framework will depend on SQLite3. Rather than making SQLite3 a required dependency of ign-transport, we can create a log (or logging) component library, and thereby isolate the dependency to the optional component.

Adding a namespace provides both developers and users with a clear delineation between the main library and the component library.

content.raw: Technically a new namespace is not required, but I think it's extremely beneficial for both users and developers to isolate components into namespaces. That way, there's a clear delineation between the separate libraries.
content.html: Technically a new namespace is not required, but I think it's extremely beneficial for both users and developers to isolate components into namespaces. That way, there's a clear delineation between the separate libraries.

content.raw:
It looks like `Log` might become the interface to logging. If this is the case, I don't see the advantage of creating a new namespace. The new sub-directory also doesn't add much value.

We can always make this more complicated (namespaces, sub-directories) if the code requires it. I prefer to start simple, and then make things more complex when there is a clear need. 

There might be clear need right now...
content.html:
It looks like Log might become the interface to logging. If this is the case, I don't see the advantage of creating a new namespace. The new sub-directory also doesn't add much value.

We can always make this more complicated (namespaces, sub-directories) if the code requires it. I prefer to start simple, and then make things more complex when there is a clear need.

There might be clear need right now...

content.raw: Right, I think the namespaces should be consistent with the directories.
content.html: Right, I think the namespaces should be consistent with the directories.

content.raw: I don't think there is a technical reason requiring a namespace. Are you saying you'd rather put everything into one namespace?
content.html: I don't think there is a technical reason requiring a namespace. Are you saying you'd rather put everything into one namespace?

content.raw: Does this require a new namespace?
content.html: Does this require a new namespace?

content.raw: I assume you mean changing not just the namespace, but all directories too?
content.html: I assume you mean changing not just the namespace, but all directories too?

content.raw: We could consider cutting down on namespace characters by naming the component `log` instead of `logging`, but I'm okay with `logging` if that's what others prefer.
content.html: We could consider cutting down on namespace characters by naming the component log instead of logging, but I'm okay with logging if that's what others prefer.
